section.title: Objective and Overview

note.para: The most fundamental capability of GMAT is to propagate, or simulate the orbital motion of, spacecraft. The ability to propagate spacecraft is used in nearly every practical aspect of space mission analysis, from simple orbital predictions (e.g. When will the International Space Station be over my house?) to complex analyses that determine the thruster firing sequence required to send a spacecraft to the Moon or Mars.

section.para: This tutorial will teach you how to use GMAT to propagate a spacecraft. You will learn how to configure Spacecraft and Propagator resources, and how to use the Propagate command to propagate the spacecraft to orbit perigee, which is the point of minimum distance between the spacecraft and Earth. The basic steps in this tutorial are:

listitem.para: Configure a Spacecraft and define its epoch and orbital elements.
Configure a Propagator.
Modify the default OrbitView plot to visualize the spacecraft trajectory.
Modify the Propagate command to propagate the spacecraft to perigee.
Run the mission and analyze the results.

section.title: Configure the Spacecraft
section.para:
In this section, you will rename the default Spacecraft and set the Spacecraft’s initial epoch and classical orbital elements. You’ll need GMAT open, with the default mission loaded. To load the default mission, click New Mission (
) or start a new GMAT session.

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, right-click DefaultSC, and select Rename.
In the Rename dialog box, type Sat .
Click OK.
In the Resources Tree, double-click on Sat. Click the Orbit tab if it is not already selected.
In the Epoch Format box, select UTCGregorian. You’ll see the value in the Epoch field change to the UTC Gregorian epoch format.
In in the Epoch field, type 22 Jul 2014 11:29:10.811. This field is case-sensitive.
Click Apply to save these changes.
In the StateType box select Keplerian . In the Elements list, you will see the GUI reconfigure to display the Keplerian state representation.
In the SMA box, type 83474.318.
Set the remaining orbital elements as shown in the table below.
Click OK.
In the Toolbar, Click the Save button. If this is the first time you have saved the mission, you’ll be prompted to provide a name and location for the file.

section.title: Configure the Propagator
section.para: In this section you’ll rename the Propagator, and configure the force model.

section.title: Rename the Propagator
section.para: Here you’ll rename the propagator with a more descriptive name:

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, right-click DefaultProp and click Rename.
In the Rename dialog box, type LowEarthProp.
Click OK.

section.title: Configure the Force Model
section.para: Now configure the force model. For this tutorial you will use an Earth 10x10 spherical harmonic model, Jacchia-Roberts atmospheric model, solar radiation pressure, and point mass perturbations from the Sun and Moon.

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, double-click LowEarthProp,
In the Gravity list, type 10 in the Degree box.
In the Order box, Type 10.
In Atmosphere Model box, select JacchiaRoberts.
Click the Select button next to the Point Masses text box. This opens the CelestialBodySelect dialog box.
In the Available Bodies list, click Sun, then click -> to add Sun to the Selected Bodies list.
Add the moon (named Luna in GMAT) using the same procedure above.
Click Use Solar Radiation Pressure to toggle it on.
Click OK.

section.title: Configuring the Orbit View Plot
section.para: Below you will configure an OrbitView plot so you can visualize Sat and its trajectory. The orbit of Sat is highly eccentric. To view the entire orbit in the plot, we need to adjust the settings of DefaultOrbitView.

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, double-click on DefaultOrbitView.
In the three boxes next to ViewPointVector, type the values -60000, 30000, and 20000 respectively.
In the Drawing Options list, un-check DrawXY Plane.
Click OK.

section.title: Configure the Propagate Command
section.para: This is the last step in the tutorial before running the mission. Below you will configure a Propagate command to propagate (model the motion of) Sat to orbit perigee.

listitem.para: Click the Mission tab to bring the Mission Tree to the foreground.
Double-click on Propagate1.
In the Stopping Conditions list, click the (...) button next to Sat.ElapsedSecs to bring up the Parameter Select Dialog
In the Object list, select Sat if it is not already selected. This directs GMAT to associate the stopping condition with the spacecraft Sat.
In the Object Properties list, double-click Periapsis to add it to the Selected Values list as shown in .

figure.title: Propagate Command Parameter Select Dialog Configuration

listitem.para: Click OK.

section.title: Run and Analyze the Results
section.para: Congratulations, you have now configured your first GMAT mission and are ready to run the mission and analyze the results.

listitem.para: Click the Save button in the Toolbar to save your mission.
Click the Run button in the Toolbar.

section.para: You will see GMAT propagate the orbit and stop at orbit periapsis. below illustrates what you should see after correctly completing this tutorial. Here are a few things you can try to explore the results of this tutorial:

listitem.para: Manipulate the Orbit View plot using your mouse to orient the trajectory so that you can to verify that at the final location the spacecraft is at perigee.
Click the Mission Tab to bring the Mission Tree to the foreground.
Right-click Propagate1 and select Command Summary to see data on the final state of Sat.
What values for longitude and latitude do you see for Sat.
Are the values for the final longitude and latitude of Sat consistent with the Ground Track plot Sat?
Close the Command Summary dialog box.
Click in the DefaultOrbitView graphics window to bring the window to the foreground.
Click Start Animation in the Toolbar to animate the mission and watch the orbit propagate from apogee to perigee.
